thread.title: Trump clarifies 'Sweden' remark, says he was referring to Fox News report
thread.title_full: Trump clarifies 'Sweden' remark, says he was referring to Fox News report

title: Trump clarifies 'Sweden' remark, says he was referring to Fox News report
text:
Trump clarifies 'Sweden' remark, says he was referring to Fox News report Published February 19, 2017 Facebook 0 Twitter 0 livefyre Email Print 

President Trump on Sunday attempted to clarify his remark at a weekend rally that suggested a terror attack had taken place Friday night in Sweden. 
“My statement as to what's happening in Sweden was in reference to a story that was broadcast on @FoxNews concerning immigrants & Sweden,” the president tweeted. 
White House Deputy Press Secretary Sarah Sanders told reporters in Florida that Trump was "talking about rising crime and recent incidents in general, and not referring to a specific incident." 
Friday night's edition of "Tucker Carlson Tonight" featured an interview with documentary filmmaker Ami Horowitz about a surge in violent crime in Sweden. Some have traced the crime increase to a surge in the number of refugees entering Sweden from Africa, Asia and the Middle East. 
Trump said at a campaign-style rally Saturday outside Melbourne, Fla.: “We’ve got to keep our country safe. You look at what’s happening in Germany, you look at what’s happening last night in Sweden. Sweden, who would believe this?” 
Trump has made securing the United States from outsiders, particularly radical Islamic terrorists, a major part of presidential campaign and now his administration. 
The president's mention of Sweden along with Germany resulted in Trump critics saying he had mistakenly referred to a terror attack. 
Last December, a terrorist drove a truck through a Christmas market in Berlin, killing 12 people and injuring roughly 50 others. The ISIS terror group took responsibility for the attack. 
Trump’s comment at the rally Saturday follows White House special counselor to the president Kellyanne Conway mistakenly citing a “massacre” in Bowling Green, Ky. 
Trump’s Sweden comment was also questioned by the Swedish Embassy and Trump critics, including Chelsea Clinton, the daughter of Hillary Clinton, the 2016 Democratic presidential nominee whom Trump defeated. 
“Unclear to us what President Trump was referring to, have asked US officials for explanation,” the embassy tweeted. What happened in Sweden Friday night? Did they catch the Bowling Green Massacre perpetrators? — Chelsea Clinton (@ChelseaClinton) February 19, 2017 
Clinton tweeted: “What happened in Sweden Friday night? Did they catch the Bowling Green Massacre perpetrators?” 
Fox News producer Jennifer Bowman contributed to this report. Advertisement
